00040 #ifndef _world_cpp
00041 #define _world_cpp
00042 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00043 //The world that integrates everything
00044 //
00045 //This is where all the calls to the the underlying libraries should be from.
00046 //World is an abstraction layer to all of the non-ui libraries. The ui
00047 //layers wx and ogre both have their own main loops, so it is almost mandatory
00048 //for other code to interact with those libraries directly.
00049 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////

00082     /// @todo TODO Fix the `const`ness of all methods to be as const as allowable
00083     World::World()
00084     {
00085         Vector3 Lbounds(-1000.0,-1000.0,-1000.0);
00086         Vector3 Ubounds(1000.0,1000.0,1000.0);
00087 
00088         this->Construct(
00089             Lbounds,
00090             Ubounds,
00091             10
00092             );
00093     }

00097     World::World(   const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_,
00098                             const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_,
00099                             const unsigned short int  &MaxPhysicsProxies_)
00100     {
00101         this->Construct(GeographyLowerBounds_,
00102                         GeographyUpperbounds_,
00103                         MaxPhysicsProxies_
00104                         );

00106 
00107     void World::Construct(  const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_,
00108                                 const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_,
00109                                 const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies_)
00110     {
00111         //Set some sane Defaults for some values
00112         this->SetWindowName("AppName");
00113         this->TargetFrameLength=16;
00114         this->HasSDLBeenInitialized=false;
00115 
00116         this->Actors = new ActorContainerVector(this);
00117         this->VisualSettings = new GraphicsSettings();
00118 
00119         //We create our Ogre environment
00120         this->OgreRoot = new Ogre::Root(crossplatform::GetPluginsDotCFG(),crossplatform::GetSettingsDotCFG(),"Physgame.log");
00121         this->OgreResource = Ogre::ResourceGroupManager::getSingletonPtr();
00122 
00123         //Callbacks are the main way that a game using the World will be able to have their code run at custom times
00124         this->CallBacks = new CallBackManager(this);
00125         //Events are the main way for the game using the world to  get information about the various subsystems
00126         this->Events = new EventManager(this);
00127 
00128         this->Physics = new PhysicsManager(this,GeographyLowerBounds_,GeographyUpperbounds_,MaxPhysicsProxies_);
00129 
00130         // This Tests various assumptions about the way the platform works, and will not act
00131         SanityChecks();
00132 
00133     }
00134 
00135     void World::SanityChecks()
00136     {
00137         //Perform a Test that only needs to be done once for the SDL/Physuserinputevent system.
00138         Log("Verifying size of userinput events:");
00139         Log(sizeof(MetaCode::InputCode));
00140         Log(sizeof(SDLKey));
00141         Log(sizeof(int));
00142         if(sizeof(MetaCode::InputCode) != sizeof(SDLKey))
00143         {
00144             LogAndThrow("User input subsystem Event Sizes  Don't match, userinput subsystem will go down faster than 'that' girl on prom night.");
00145         }else{
00146             Log("External User input subsystem Event Sizes match, the User Input subsystem won't crash instantly");
00147         }
00148 
00149         if(sizeof(MetaCode::InputCode) != sizeof(int))
00150         {
00151             LogAndThrow("Internal User input subsystem Event Sizes Don't match, userinput subsystem cannot function.");
00152         }else{
00153             Log("Internal User input subsystem Event Sizes match, the User Input subsystem won't crash instantly");
00154         }
00155 
00156         TestLogger();
00157     }

00228     template <class T> void World::OneLogTest(T Data, string DataType, string Message1, string Message2)
00229     {
00230         try
00231         {
00232             Log(Message1+DataType);
00233             LogAndThrow(Data);
00234         } catch (T excepted) {
00235             Log(Message2+DataType);
00236             Log(excepted);
00237         }
00238     }

00240     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00241     //tears the world down
00242     World::~World()
00243     {
00244 
00245 
00246         //All the pointers Ogre made should get taken care of by OGRE
00247         delete OgreRoot;
00248 
00249         //clear up our objects
00250         delete CallBacks;
00251         delete Events;
00252 
00253         delete VisualSettings;
00254 
00255         delete Physics;
00256 
00257         //remove sdl stuff
00258         SDL_FreeSurface(SDLscreen);
00259         SDL_Quit();
00260     }

00262     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00263     //appends to the gamelog which is managed by Ogre
00264     template <class T> void World::Log(T Message)
00265     {
00266         stringstream temp;
00267         temp << Message;
00268         Ogre::LogManager::getSingleton().logMessage(temp.str());
00269     }
00270 
00271     template <class T> void World::LogAndThrow(T Message)
00272     {
00273         this->Log(Message);
00274         throw(Message);
00275     }

00278     //Shows the ogre settings Dialog, and allows it to save settings to ogres
00279     //preset save location
00280     bool World::ShowSystemSettingDialog()
00281     {
00282         try
00283         {
00284             return this->OgreRoot->showConfigDialog();
00285         } catch (exception& e) {
00286             this->Log("Ogre settings windows from main UI or mandatory setting failure");
00287             this->Log(e.what());
00288             return false;
00289         }
00290     }

00292     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00293     // Start the Game already
00294     void World::GameInit(const bool &CallMainLoop )
00295     {
00296         //try to load the ogre config
00297         this->LoadOgreSettings();
00298         this->CreateRenderWindow();
00299 
00300         //Initiliaze the Physics Debug Drawer
00301         this->Physics->Initialize();
00302 
00303         if(CallMainLoop)
00304         {
00305             MainLoop();
00306         }
00307     }
00308 
00309     void World::MainLoop()
00310     {
00311         //Create a the RenderTimer, which will be used to measure the time
00312         Ogre::Timer RenderTimer;
00313 
00314         bool Callbackbools[] = {true, true, true, true, true, true};
00315 
00316         //Used for tracking times to prevent Infinite render loops in graphically simple games
00317         //Whole Times[] = {0,0,0,0};
00318 
00319         this->OgreSceneManager->setAmbientLight( Ogre::ColourValue( 1, 1, 1 ) );
00320 
00321         Whole FrameDelay = 0;
00322         Whole FrameTime = 0;
00323 
00324         /*! @page mainloop1 Main Loop Structure and Flow
00325          The MainLoop is heart of most vidoe games and simulations.
00326 
00327          @section mainloopoverview1 Main loop Overview
00328          The Main loop runs in World.MainLoop() which is called by default from @ref World.GameInit(). By default this Method also starts the render, the physics andthe input systems. It does very little
00329          on it's own. It uses the default callback manager (which you can swap out if you want), which is the callback manager point to by World::CallBacks . Once started it runs the
00330          callbacks present in the callback manager until one of them returns false. It has a pretty specific work flow. Starting with input, then physics, then rendering. There is a callback
00331          before and after each of these tasks.
00332          \n \n The user input task is never started if there is no Pre or Post callback set. It won't crash or throw any weird error condtions, it was specifically designed this way. This
00333          allows the input buffering to be turned off by simply removing the callbacks. This might not sound like much, but if you simply don't need input this can be a little performance bump.
00334          It sounds even better when we say it works the same way for physics. If you do not have a pre or post physic callback set physics simply is not run. This allows for easy control over
00335          the state of motion  in a world. Currently Rendering is performed each iteration of the main loop, regardless of what Callbacks are set. This may be changed at some point in the future,
00336          but no immediate plans to change it are in the works.
00337          \n \n One iteration of the main loops is about 1/60 of a second (by default) and will render 1 frame and step physics about 1/60 (1/62.5 usually) of a second. Currently there is no way to uncap
00338          the framerate, we did not see a need for more (but the cap can be adjusted using World::SetTargetFrameTime or World::SetTargetFrameRate ). Situations with low performance should
00339          automatically be handled but increasing the size of physics
00340          steps and automatically not rendering frames when not appropriate. There will be fewer calls on callbacks, but the engine will not inhibit gameplay below the the target framerate.
00341         \n
00342          @section callbacks1 1) Input Callbacks and Buffering
00343          User input is the first task performed each main loop. This was done because in most games and simulations everything depends on the user input.
00344          @subsection input1 1.A) PreInputCallback
00345          This can be set using the function in PhysWorldCallBackManager that have "PreInput" in their names. This is a great place to to do begining of loop items, like gathering data for
00346          computer controlled characters, checking if game goals are met, and other items that needs to be done it iteration of the game loop and don't directly relate to physics or Rendering.
00347          @subsection input2 1.B) Input Buffering
00348          During this step Input events are gathered fromt the input Subsystem (which could be any of a number of user input libraries), which are ultimately made by the Operating System and
00349          processed into EventUserInput objects, and placed in the Default event manager ( check the pointer World::Events ).
00350          @subsection input3 1.C) PostInputCallback
00351          This callback is your first chance to access the userinput Events and try to use them. This callback can be managed by using methods in PhysWorldCallBackManager that have "PostInput"
00352          in their names. The functionality of this Callback slightly overlaps with the Prephysics Callbacks due to the timing of using them both. If both are used, one will be called
00353          immediately after the other.
00354         \n
00355          @section callbacks2 2) Physics callbacks and Event Buffering
00356          This step runs between user input and rendering to allow for changes caused by user input to be immediately visible to the user.
00357          @subsection physics1 2.A) PrePhysicsCallback
00358          The funtionality of this callback overlaps a great deal with the PostInputCallBack, but they both still exist to make organization easier when needed. You probably should have figured
00359          out by now how the Callbackmanager functions are named, the ones for this are ituitively named with "PrePhysics" in their name.
00360          @subsection physics2 2.B) Physics calculations and Event Buffering
00361          Physics will be run here, but currently is not fully implemented. But eventually physics event will be generated here. Including a system for checking for certain types of collisions.
00362          @subsection physics3 2.C) PostPhysicsCallback
00363          This Callback is you first chance to work with the physics events just generated. This is a good place to check if you want items to adjust hitpoints, explode, die or take some other
00364          action based on physics.
00365         \n
00366          @section callbacks3 3) Rendering
00367          Unlike Input and Physics this rendering will be performed each Frame regardless of what callbacks are set. Rendering is done
00368          last so that any changes to the game world physics makes are made visible in the same loop iteration.
00369          @subsection rendering1 3.A) PerRenderCallback
00370          Any tasks that could not be complete in the PostPhysics Callback can be performed here or you use this to make last minute
00371          preparations for rendering.
00372          @subsection rendering2 3.B) Rendering
00373          This is where the rendering actually occurs. The state of all the items in the world is grabbed from the physics subsystem
00374          and rendered. Additionally this is where the FrameDelay is calculated and acted on, so the frame rate can stay consistent.
00375          @subsection rendering3 3.C) PostRenderCallback
00376          This is a great place to switch out the Callback Manager, for accomplishing tasks like switching between in game menus and
00377          actual gameplay. This is also a decent place to get a head start on anything that would be run in the PreInputCallback.
00378         \n
00379          @section endingmainloop1 Ending the Main Loop
00380          The main loop stores the return values of each of the 6 callbacks. If they are all true the mainloop continues to it's
00381          next iteration. If one or more of any of the callbacks returns false then the main loop ends, and the game engine exits
00382          gracefully, cleanly up the physics, graphics and any others subsystems it opened.
00383          No attempt will be made by the engine to clean up data in the callback manager. If the game code does not free these items
00384          the operating system had better do it automatically. On most PC platform this is not an issue, but it could be disastrous
00385          on a mobile, or underperforming gaming platform.
00386         */
00387         //As long as all the CallBacks return true the game continues
00388         while (Callbackbools[0] && Callbackbools[1] && Callbackbools[2] && Callbackbools[3] && Callbackbools[4] && Callbackbools[5])
00389         {
00390             //Input buffering Callbacks
00391             if( this->CallBacks->IsPreInputCallbackSet() || this->CallBacks->IsPostInputCallbackSet() )
00392             {
00393                 if( this->CallBacks->IsPreInputCallbackSet() )
00394                     { Callbackbools[0] = this->CallBacks->PreInput(); }
00395                 this->DoMainLoopInputBuffering();
00396                 if( this->CallBacks->IsPostInputCallbackSet() )
00397                     { Callbackbools[1] = this->CallBacks->PostInput(); }
00398             }
00399 
00400             //Physics & Physics Callbacks
00401             if( this->CallBacks->IsPrePhysicsCallbackSet() || this->CallBacks->IsPostPhysicsCallbackSet() )
00402             {
00403                 if( this->CallBacks->IsPrePhysicsCallbackSet() )
00404                     { Callbackbools[2] = this->CallBacks->PrePhysics(); }
00405                 this->DoMainLoopPhysics(FrameTime);
00406                 if( this->CallBacks->IsPostPhysicsCallbackSet() )
00407                     { Callbackbools[3] = this->CallBacks->PostPhysics(); }
00408             }
00409 
00410             //PreRender callback
00411             if(this->CallBacks->IsPreRenderCallbackSet())
00412             {
00413                 Callbackbools[4] = this->CallBacks->PreRender();
00414                 this->DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering();
00415             }
00416 
00417             //Render the frame and figure the amount of time it took //By default Limit frame rate to 62.5
00418             this->DoMainLoopRender();
00419 
00420             // Do Time Calculations to Determine Rendering Time
00421             FrameTime = RenderTimer.getMilliseconds();
00422             RenderTimer.reset();
00423             if(this->TargetFrameLength>FrameTime){
00424                 FrameDelay++;
00425             }else if(this->TargetFrameLength==FrameTime){
00426             }else{
00427                 if (0<FrameDelay){
00428                     FrameDelay--;
00429                 }else{
00430                     FrameDelay=0;
00431                 }
00432             }
00433             crossplatform::WaitMilliseconds( FrameDelay );
00434 
00435             //PostRender Callback
00436             if(this->CallBacks->IsPostRenderCallbackSet())
00437             {
00438                 this->Events->AddEvent(new EventRenderTime(FrameTime));
00439                 Callbackbools[5] = this->CallBacks->PostRender();
00440             }
00441 
00442         }//End of main loop
00443 
00444         //Some after loop cleanup
00445         this->DestroyRenderWindow();
00446     }
00447 
00448     void World::MoveCamera(const Vector3 &Position, const Vector3 &LookAt)
00449     {
00450         this->OgreCamera->setPosition(Ogre::Vector3(Position.X,Position.Y,Position.Z));
00451         this->OgreCamera->lookAt(Ogre::Vector3(LookAt.X,LookAt.Y,LookAt.Z));
00452     }
00453 
00454     void World::DoMainLoopAllItems(const Real &PreviousFrameTime)
00455     {
00456         this->DoMainLoopPhysics(PreviousFrameTime);
00457         this->DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering();
00458         this->DoMainLoopInputBuffering();
00459         this->DoMainLoopRender();
00460     }
00461 
00462     void World::DoMainLoopPhysics(const Real &TimeElapsed)
00463     {
00464         this->Physics->DoMainLoopItems(TimeElapsed);
00465         Log("Updated Physics");
00466     }
00467 
00468     void World::DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering()
00469     {
00470         this->Events->UpdateSystemEvents();
00471     }
00472 
00473     void World::DoMainLoopInputBuffering()
00474     {
00475         this->Events->UpdateUserInputEvents();
00476     }
00477 
00478     void World::DoMainLoopRender()
00479     {
00480         crossplatform::RenderPhysWorld(this);
00481     }

00486     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00487     //Loads the Ogre Configuration
00488     void World::LoadOgreSettings()
00489     {
00490         //Try loading from the default location
00491         if (!this->OgreRoot->restoreConfig())
00492         {
00493             //if we can't do that then lets make new settings
00494             if (!this->ShowSystemSettingDialog())
00495             {
00496                 this->LogAndThrow("Error 1: Could not setup Ogre.");
00497             }
00498         }
00499     }
00500 
00501     //Seriously read the Function Name
00502     void World::CreateRenderWindow()
00503     {
00504         /// @todo TODO set multithreaded SDL so it will the run event manager in another thread
00505         //Get what is needed for SDL started
00506         if (SDL_Init(SDL_INIT_VIDEO) < 0) {
00507             this->Log("Error 2: Unable to init SDL, SDL Error Follows:");
00508             this->LogAndThrow(SDL_GetError());
00509         }
00510         this->HasSDLBeenInitialized=true;
00511 
00512         //Setup the SDL render window
00513         this->SDLscreen = SDL_SetVideoMode( VisualSettings->getRenderWidth(), VisualSettings->getRenderHeight(),0, SDL_OPENGL);
00514         SDL_WM_SetCaption(this->WindowName.c_str(), NULL);
00515 
00516         //Start Ogre Without a native render window
00517         this->OgreGameWindow = this->OgreRoot->initialise(false, this->WindowName);
00518 
00519         //Configure Ogre to render to the SDL window
00520         Ogre::NameValuePairList *misc;
00521         misc=(Ogre::NameValuePairList*) crossplatform::GetSDLOgreBinder();
00522         (*misc)["title"] = Ogre::String(this->WindowName);
00523         this->OgreGameWindow = this->OgreRoot->createRenderWindow(WindowName, VisualSettings->getRenderHeight(), VisualSettings->getRenderWidth(), VisualSettings->getFullscreen(), misc);
00524 
00525         //prepare a scenemanager
00526         this->OgreSceneManager = this->OgreRoot->createSceneManager(Ogre::ST_GENERIC,"SceneManager");
00527 
00528         //setup a default camera
00529         this->Cameras = new CameraManager (this->OgreSceneManager);
00530         this->Cameras->CreateCamera();
00531         this->OgreCamera = this->Cameras->DefaultCamera;
00532         this->OgreCamera->setNearClipDistance(5.0f);
00533         this->OgreCamera->setFarClipDistance(5000.0f);
00534 
00535         //this->MoveCamera(Vector3(0.0f,0.0f,500.0f), Vector3(0.0f,0.0f,0.0f));
00536 
00537         //viewport connects camera and render window
00538         this->OgreViewport = this->OgreGameWindow->addViewport(OgreCamera);
00539 
00540         //setting the aspect ratio must be done after we setup the viewport
00541         this->OgreCamera->setAspectRatio( Ogre::Real(OgreViewport->getActualWidth()) / Ogre::Real(OgreViewport->getActualHeight()) );
00542     }
00543 
00544     void World::DestroyRenderWindow()
00545     {
00546         this->OgreGameWindow->destroy();
00547     }
00548

00553     void World::AddActor(ActorBase* ActorToAdd)
00554     {
00555         ActorToAdd->AddObjectToWorld(this, this->Physics->BulletDynamicsWorld);
00556         this->Actors->AddActor(ActorToAdd);
00557     }
00558 
00559     void World::RemoveActor(ActorBase* ActorToRemove)
00560     {
00561         ActorToRemove->RemoveObjectFromWorld(this, this->Physics->BulletDynamicsWorld);
00562         this->Actors->RemoveActor(ActorToRemove);
00563     }

00570         return this->WindowName;
00571     }

00573     void World::SetWindowName(const String &NewName)
00574     {
00575         /// @todo TODO Change the name of an application once it is running
00576         WindowName = NewName;
00577         if(this->HasSDLBeenInitialized)
00578         {
00579             SDL_WM_SetCaption(WindowName.c_str(),WindowName.c_str());
00580         }
00581     }

00584     {

00586     }

00593     void World::SetTargetFrameRate(const Whole &NewFrameRate)
00594     {
00595         this->SetTargetFrameTime( 1000/NewFrameRate );
